Each time a package is added to the bundle or the discount percentage change, then all collaborators must approve their game for inclusion into the bundle before it can be published.

SteamworksEvents_BuildingCommunity_Gauta: Over the last 15 years Gautam has worked on numerous Valve franchises and products including Left 4 Dead, Portal , Half-Life, Counter-Strike, Alien Swarm, and Steam.  Currently he is contributing on CS:GO.
SteamworksEvents_BuildingCommunity_Adil: Adil is part of the Steam software development team. He has built features across the Steam technology stack. Most recently working on tech to support Events, Sales, and Live Streaming.
SteamworksEvents_BuildingCommunity_Alden: Alden Kroll, designer at Valve. Alden has been a designer at Valve for over 15 years, working on Steam as well as on games such as Team Fortress 2, Portal, and Left 4 Dead. Alden is currently working at the intersection of design, business, and communication as a designer on the Steam store and the Steamworks publishing tools, as well as helping organize developer outreach and communication.
SteamworksEvents_BuildingCommunity_Jenny: Jenny Windom - Communications Manager at Rose City Games

Jenny is passionate about indie games, their communities, and advocating for representation across all levels of the industry. Her work includes Communications Manager for Rose City Games (The World Next Door, Floppy Knights, Garden Story), Communications for Kowloon Nights, and freelance indie game curator and content creator!
SteamworksEvents_BuildingCommunity_JoeTi: Joe Tirado - Communications and Marketing Lead at System Era Softworks
SteamworksEvents_BuildingCommunity_Joe: Joe is an artist, designer, and diversity advocate. While at System Era Softworks, Joe was part of the development team behind Astroneer, garnering awards in 2019 for “Best Adventure Game” at the Webby Awards and the “Gamer’s Voice Award” at the SXSW Game Awards. He is also the co-founder of Latinx in Gaming, serving as a platform to connect and represent Latinos across the gaming industry.
SteamworksEvents_BuildingCommunity_Sessi: Alden Kroll & Adil Sardar - Valve Corporation

This session is a step-by-step walkthrough of the Steam Events & Announcements, led by some of the folks who built the feature. Learn the basics, see the tools in action, and hear best practices to get the most out of Steam’s communication tools.

Counter-Strike: Global Offensive has a big, global community of players. In his talk, Gautam will go into detail about how the CS:GO team uses content and game changes to communicate with such a broad audience. He’ll also share some perspective on how a game team can manage the tradeoffs between when to talk, and when to listen.

Sometimes it can feel like player communication and events are only useful for big online multiplayer games, but in this conversation Jenny helps to prove otherwise. This session focuses on some of the strategies and techniques used to build community and engagement around two smaller single-player games: Garden Story, an upcoming adventure RPG developed by Picogram, and Floppy Knights, a card battler developed by Rose City Games.

Astroneer first released as a Steam Early Access title back in late 2016. Almost five years later, the game continues to resonate with players new and old. Joe shares lessons about how a small team can use communication to involve players early in the development process and how to handle feedback throughout the life of a game.

OptIn_EmailSection_MediaPermission_Body_: Your game's trailer is in consideration to be included in our official marketing materials for the upcoming Steam Event.

Specifically, we'd like to pull a short segment or two from the publicly visible trailer(s) listed on your Steam store page for your game to use in a trailer we're putting together to promote this official Steam event. This trailer will go live on (or around) the Thursday before the event starts to help get players and press excited about the upcoming event. Our promo trailer will be posted to some combination of the official Steam YouTube channel, the official Steam event page (when the event is live), and Steam social media channels, and will also be distributed to press.
If you are willing to let us use your trailer in this way, please let us know by following the link below and granting permission by %1$s.
OptIn_EmailSection_NextFest_QASession_Ti: JOIN US LIVE WITH YOUR QUESTIONS
OptIn_EmailSection_NextFest_QASession_Bo: Join us live on %1$s for a one-hour virtual Q&A session, when a few of us from Valve will be available to answer your questions about preparing for Steam Next Fest. Drop in and stick your question in chat and we'll try to get to them all. %2$s
OptIn_EmailSection_NextFest_Returns_Body: Steam Next Fest is a multi-day celebration where fans can try out demos, chat with developers, watch livestreams, and learn about upcoming games on Steam. For developers, Steam Next Fest is an opportunity to get early feedback from players and build an audience for a future launch on Steam.
OptIn_EmailSection_NextFest_WhatNext_Bod: Be sure to give yourself enough time to finish the demo (and have it reviewed) before the festival starts on %1$s. You are free to tell your fans you'll be participating, whenever it makes sense for you to do so.
OptIn_EmailSection_NextFest_Tips_Body: Looking for some advice and tips as you work on building and preparing your playable demo? Check out our %1$s that we've gathered from developers who participated in past editions of Next Fest. Plus, visit the %2$s for recordings of past Q&A sessions where members of the Steam Business team answered developers' questions about registering for and getting the most out of Steam Next Fest.
OptIn_EmailSection_NextFest_StartsNow_Bo: We're thrilled to be kicking off this edition of Steam Next Fest with you today and can't wait to see your demo in action. Thanks so much for participating and for making the fest a can't-miss event!
OptIn_EmailSection_NextFest_ThankYou_Bod: Thank you for helping make Steam Next Fest possible! We saw millions of players try out demos, wishlist games, and watch livestreams across the weeklong event. We hope you also found the event valuable in helping you move closer to a successful game release on Steam.
OptIn_EmailSection_TrailerDemoPermission: Can we use your trailer(s) and/or demo gameplay?
Your game's trailer and/or demo is in consideration to be included in our official marketing materials for %1$s.

Specifically, we'd like to pull a short segment(s) from the publicly visible trailer(s) listed on your game's Steam store page and/or demo gameplay to use in our official livestream, main event trailer, and/or genre trailers we're putting together to promote %1$s.
The main event trailer will go live on or around %1$s in conjunction with the Press Preview to help get players and press excited about the upcoming event.
The livestream and genre trailers will go live on %1$s the first day of the event, during the official %2$s broadcast.

Our livestream and trailers will be posted to some combination of the %1$s event page (when the event is live), Steam social media channels, the official Steam YouTube channel, and the official Steam Twitch channel, and will also be distributed to press.

In addition to opting in here, you must have at least one trailer publicly available and a playable build of your demo submitted for review and approved by %1$s. This deadline is firm. You may continue to update your demo at any time after it has been approved and may publicly release your demo at any time you choose prior to the event start.

If you authorize trailer use and we use your game's trailer(s), we'll make use of one that is publicly visible on your store page as of %1$s. If you authorize gameplay use, we may grant our %2$s event team access to the demo using Release Override Steam keys anytime after %1$s up until the event starts, and the team will decide whether to use the demo gameplay.

If you're willing to let us use your trailer(s) and/or demo gameplay in this way, please let us know by following the link below and completing the opt-in form, making at least one trailer publicly available on your store page, and submitting a playable build of your demo with enough time for review and approval confirmed by %1$s. Note that this is not a guarantee your materials will be used.
See demo and trailer usage part of OptIn
OptIn_EmailSection_ThankYou_Body: Thank you for helping make this event possible! Over the course of the event, we saw tons of players exploring, finding deals, wishlisting games, and playing demos. We hope you also found the event valuable in helping you reach new customers.
OptIn_EmailSection_TrailerDemoPermission: If you haven't already and would like to do so, please opt in to give us permission to potentially use your trailer in our marketing materials by completing the dedicated trailer permissions section in the event opt-in:
REMINDER TO SUBMIT YOUR STORE ASSETS AND DEMO BUILD FOR REVIEW

In order to remain in consideration for inclusion after opting in, you must also have at least one publicly visible trailer on your store page and have a playable build of your demo submitted for review and approved by %1$s. This deadline is firm; we suggest submitting your demo for review at least a week prior to the deadline.
You may continue to update your demo at any time and may publicly release your demo any time you choose prior to the event start.

OptIn_EmailSection_SeasonalFeaturing_Bod: We'd like to feature your game on the front page in the upcoming Seasonal Sale. If you are interested, and you intend to run a discount, we need you to register by %1$s.

Featured titles are included in a pool of games that are displayed prominently on the Front Page during the sale. The system is designed to prioritize titles based on customer preferences, wishlists, languages, etc. with the goal of showcasing titles that are relevant to each individual customer.

You don't need to immediately enter your discounts (though that would be nice) but we do need to know whether you intend to participate or not. Either way, please click the button below and indicate your intent by %1$s.
OptIn_EmailSection_SeasonalDiscounting_B: We find it's valuable to be a more aggressive with discounts during the Seasonal Sales than you might have been in the past. The Seasonal Sales are unique in the number of titles that are discounted simultaneously, and customers are specifically shopping for value.  We encourage you to consider running a deeper discount than you have in the past.
If you have questions about registration, or would like to discuss discounting further, please %1$s.
Please note that opting-in to this form does not guarantee Featured Placement for the upcoming Sale. Valve reserves the right to adjust featuring for any reason.

OptIn_NextFest_Q1: How satisfied were you with the communication from Valve about Next Fest?
OptIn_NextFest_Q1_A1: <1>Excellent</1> I totally understood the process and deadlines
OptIn_NextFest_Q1_A2: <1>It was fine</1> I mostly understood what to do and when the deadlines were
OptIn_NextFest_Q1_A3: <1>Unsatisfied</1> I found the process unclear or confusing
OptIn_NextFest_Q1_Notes: Could you describe what part you found to be unclear or confusing?
OptIn_NextFest_Q2: How many full-time people do you have working on your game?
OptIn_NextFest_Q2_A1: <1>0</1> One or more, but only working part-time on the game
OptIn_NextFest_Q3: Did your participation in Next Fest meet your expectations?
OptIn_NextFest_Q3_A1: <1>Yes</1> I got what I was hoping for
OptIn_NextFest_Q3_A2: <1>No</1> I was expecting more from the event
OptIn_NextFest_Q3_Notes: Where did Next Fest come up short for you?
OptIn_NextFest_Q4: Did you change your release plans as a result of participating in Next Fest?
OptIn_NextFest_Q4_A1: <1>No</1> We're on track and forging ahead as previously planned!
OptIn_NextFest_Q4_A2: <1>Yes</1> We've changed our release date or scope of the game as a result of Next Fest
OptIn_NextFest_Q4_Notes: What changes did you make to your plans? Why?
OptIn_NextFest_Q5: Do you have any feedback or suggestions?
OptIn_NextFest_Q5_Notes: What can we do to make Next Fest better?

DailyDeals_Info_How_Overview: If your game is invited to participate in a Daily Deal, you'll recieve an email and see your game listed above. Here's how the process works from that point:
DailyDeals_Info_How1: Select an available date within the next 6 months that works for you.
DailyDeals_Info_How2: The visibility on the Steam homepage and applicable tag pages runs for 24 hours, while the discount will be active for between 7 and 14 days depending on the discount length you selected.  It will start at 10am Pacific time on your selected date.
DailyDeals_Info_How3: When you select an available date, it will prompt you to enter a discount percentage and select which packages you wish to include in the promotion.
DailyDeals_Info_How4: We ask that you pick a discount % that is at least as good as the best discount you have run in the past, if not better.
DailyDeals_Info_How5: If you are not ready to schedule your Daily Deal right now, the invite will be on your Daily Deal Dashboard.  Please keep the expiration date in mind.
DailyDeals_Info_Question: If you need to change your date, cancel or have questions - %1$s
DailyDeals_Info_Best1: We find it often beneficial to time your increased visibility and discount with other activities you might have planned, such as a game content update, livestream, or community event.
DailyDeals_Info_Best2: If you have other scheduled discounts planned within a month of your selected Daily Deal, please try to keep the discount percentage equal among those discounts. When we feature you game as a Daily Deal, we like it to be as good as or better than offers you've run before.

StoreAdmin_EditPackageDisplay_HidePrefix: Omit game name from the start of items in the package contents list.

To reduce redudancy and increase readibility, omit the game name plus whitespace and connecting characters like colons and hypthens from the start of items like DLC and soundtracks when they are listed in the package purchase area. For example, 'Half Life 2: Episode 1' will appear as 'Episode 1'. Only the exact name of the base game plus whitespace and common separators like hyphens and colons are hidden.

AssetRequest_SubTitle: The following assets are required for this type of promotion.
AssetRequest_Existing_Q1: We have some assets from a previous promo below.
AssetRequest_Existing_Q2: Is this art good to use again?
AssetRequest_Existing_Note: (of course we'll update this with new percentage and messaging as necessary)
AssetRequest_ExistingReuse: Yes, please use this artwork again
AssetRequest_ExistingNoReuse: No, let me upload something else
AssetRequest_ArtType_app_header_capsule_: Usage: This image represents your sale event in the Daily Deal spot on the homepage of Steam.
Design: Should include your event logo over a grid of your most popular games so that players can identify some games they recognize.
AssetRequest_ArtType_app_main_capsule_Us: Usage: This image represents your sale event and is sometimes used when we need to present the promotion in alternative locations.
AssetRequest_ArtType_app_main_capsule_De: Design: Should include your event logo over a grid of your most popular games so that players can identify some games they recognize.
AssetRequest_Link_Desc: Enter URL where we can download your layered PSD and any fonts you are using.
AssetRequest_Link_Step1: Upload preview files for each of the assets below (%1$s)
AssetRequest_Link_Step2: Review the preview for each asset to ensure they adhere to our sizing and clipping templates
AssetRequest_Link_Step3: Place the source .psd files and any non-standard fonts on a service like Dropbox or Google Drive or similar and send us the URL by filling it in below.
AssetRequest_General_Upload_saleheader: Upload your Sale Background Image preview
AssetRequest_General_Upload_event_capsul: Upload your Event Cover Image preview
AssetRequest_General_Upload_productbanne: Upload your Store Mobile Banner Mobile preview
AssetRequest_General_Upload_def: Upload a JPEG or PNG below to preview
AssetRequest_General_Upload_defgif: Upload a JPEG, PNG or GIF below to preview
AssetRequest_General_Upload_drag: drag your file here to upload
AssetRequest_Spotlight_Usage: Usage: Spotlight Banner appears near the top of the Steam home page and relevant Store hubs for specific promotions such as Midweek Deals or Weekend Deals.
AssetRequest_Spotlight_Design: Design: Spotlight Banner will automatically have a section rendered over the bottom with the text describing the type of promotion (eg, 'Weekend Deal') and the end dates of the promotion.
AssetRequest_Spotlight_Design2: The amount of the bottom of the image that may be covered can vary depending on the volume of text and/or language.
AssetRequest_Spotlight_Design3: Please refrain from putting key elements in the bottom 1/4 of the image.
AssetRequest_Spotlight_Design4: Otherwise, this capsule should mostly just focus on your game art and logo.
AssetRequest_MM_Usage: Usage: Steam pop-up window and on the front page of Steam
AssetRequest_MM_Design: Design: For best results, please make sure the logo is clearly legible, and include a callout to the type of promotion it is (Pre-Purchase, Now Available, Coming Soon, etc...).
AssetRequest_MM_Design1: Price and call-to-action button will automatically appear below the image.
AssetRequest_MM_Animation: Marketing Messages support animation, which should always be fairly subtle. If you explore this route, you must read our documentation linked above and adhere to our animation specifications.
AssetRequest_MM_Update_Usage: Usage: In the Steam pop-up window to communicate that this game has released a major update
AssetRequest_MM_Update_Design: Design: Should include only two elements – art and game logo
AssetRequest_MM_Update_Design1: Art: For best results, use art that represents the new content from the update such as new key art, screenshots, or new characters and features, etc.
AssetRequest_MM_Update_Design2: Logo: Can be the main game title logo, or an official logo of the game update if applicable. If there are multiple language versions of the logo for localized assets, please provide.
AssetRequest_MM_Update_Design3: Do not include any additional text in this image. Information about the event update and call-to-action will automatically appear alongside the image.
AssetRequest_MM_Update_Design5: Final upload format: JPEG, PNG, or GIF. File size < 5MB
AssetRequest_MM_Update_Design6: Please always provide layered PSD files
AssetRequest_TakeOver_Usage: Usage: Artwork that appears at the very top of the Steam Front page and/or Store hub and is a very large treatment for everyone to see.
AssetRequest_TakeOver_Design: Requires two formats, large and mobile. For the preview here, you will only upload static versions of your takeover, even if you are creating animated versions too.
AssetRequest_Takeover_Animation: Takeovers support animation, which should always be fairly subtle. If you explore this route, you must read our documentation linked above and adhere to our animation specifications.
AssetRequest_Takeunder_Usage: Usage: Artwork that appears at below the special offers section on Front page and/or Store hubs.
AssetRequest_Takeunder_Design: Requires two formats, large and mobile. Make sure there is a clear call-to-action and the dates of the event.
AssetRequest_SalePage_Description: Within sale pages, there are multiple asset types to be considered
AssetRequest_SalePage_Background_Usage: Usage: this artwork appears in the background of your sale page
AssetRequest_SalePage_Background_Design: Design: This image should include your event logo and dates well within the safe area at the top of the image. The left/right/bottom edges should fade or transition to a single solid color that is applied to the rest of your page. Please double-check the template for details.
AssetRequest_SalePage_Background_Hint: This image should be static and below 5MB, .jpg, .png
AssetRequest_SalePage_Logo_Usage: Usage: this image appears at the top of your sale page, in front of your background image.
AssetRequest_SalePage_Logo_Design: Design: This image should include your event logo and dates on a transparent background.
AssetRequest_SalePage_Cover_Usage: Usage: this artwork is used to represent your event in the Steam News Hub, on the Special Offers Page, and will appear as the preview when people share your event URL on social media
AssetRequest_SalePage_Cover_Design: Design: This image should include your event logo and dates
AssetRequest_SalePage_Header_Usage: Usage: This artwork is displayed at the top of the announcement that is associated with your sale page.
AssetRequest_SalePage_Header_Design: Design: This image is not critical; it's simply intended to add some context and color for your written announcement.
AssetRequest_SalePage_Cover_Hint: This image should be static and below 5MB, .jpg, .png
AssetRequest_SalePage_StoreBanner_Usage: Usage: This banner appears on the top of each game that is included in your event. For that reason, you need to have permission from the creators of every included game or you cannot use this feature.
AssetRequest_SalePage_StoreBanner_Design: Design: This image should include your event logo and dates and ideally include a call to action or brief tagline for your event so that players understand the context.
AssetRequest_SalePage_StoreBanner_Hint: This image should be static and below 5MB, .jpg, .png
AssetRequest_SalePage_StoreBannerMobile_: Usage: is the mobile version of the Store Page Banner. It replaces the default Store Page Banner on screens 500px or narrower.
This image should pretty closely match the contents of your default Store Page Banner
This image should be static and below 5MB, .jpg, .png
AssetRequest_Submitted_Body: Your assets have been submitted to Valve and your work here is done! The submitted assets will automatically appear on the Steam Team's dashboard to review and prepare for the promotion.
AssetRequest_Submitted: Assets Submitted! No further assets related actions required.
AssetRequest_SubmitLink: Click below to submit your promotional assets to Valve. Once submitted, the Steam Team will begin reviewing and preparing the materials for featuring.
AssetRequest_InvalidLink: Cannot submit, the above URL is malformed
AssetRequest_Intro_Desc: Please review the checklist below and send us the required assets so we can translate this offer into all the languages supported by Steam!
AssetRequest_Requirements_2: Artwork must be in layered Photoshop (PSD) files
AssetRequest_Requirements_2a: Main game/character art in highest resolution possible (smart object preferred). Doing so allows us to re-use these assets to create other Steam promotional art when necessary.
AssetRequest_Requirements_2b: Logo (smart object preferred) separated from the art.
AssetRequest_Requirements_2c: Any text should be editable in a separate “text” folder within the PSD document, so that it may be easily localized by our team.
AssetRequest_Requirements_3: Include any fonts used (especially custom fonts).
AssetRequest_Requirements_4: For animated assets, please also provide a seamless looping MP4 or PNG sequence without the text and logo. Make sure that any text is on a separate layer and not animated so it may be easily localized by our team.
AssetRequest_Requirements_5: For more details and examples, plus specifics for animated assets, please see <1>Store Promo Graphical Assets</1>
AssetRequest_Check_desc: Use the uploader below to submit a preview and to ensure your image adheres to our sizing and clipping templates.
AssetRequest_Check_AutoRenderMM_desc: The marketing message will use the existing Main Capsule, screenshots, and trailer that are visible on your game's store page.
AssetRequest_Check_PromoApp_desc: Use the uploader below to submit a preview and to ensure your image adheres to our sizing and clipping templates.
AssetRequest_Check_Takeover_desc: Use the uploader below to submit a preview both the takeover and takeover mobile to ensure your image adheres to our sizing and clipping templates.
AssetRequest_Check_Takeunder_desc: Use the uploader below to submit a preview both the takeunder banner and takeunder mobile banner to ensure your image adheres to our sizing and clipping templates.
AssetRequest_Check_SalePage_desc: Use the uploader below to submit previews of the five items related to the sale page for their localization. Ensure your images adhere to our sizing and clipping templates.
AssetRequest_Check_Special_desc: Enter any special instructions or additional information that your Steam representative should know about your assets. For example, are you including information about a cooresponding update? Are there specific brand use guidelines for any of your assets?
AssetRequest_Check_Special_placeholder: anything special to know about your assets
AssetRequest_Check_ContactInfo_desc: Enter one or more email addresses of whom we should contact if there are questsions or feedback related to the uploaded assets.
AssetRequest_Check_ContactInfo_placehold: Comma separated list of email addresses
AssetRequest_Complete_Desc: Next, the Steam promo team will review the assets and prepare the materials for your promotion. We'll be in touch if we need anything further
AssetRequest_Complete_SeeAll_Title: Want to review what you submitted?
AssetRequest_Compelte_Reminder: Don't forget to enter your discounts
AssetRequest_UpdateAnnouncement_desc: Select the announcement that contains details of your major update

App_Landing_Set_Release_Date_ComingSoonW: Your intended release date is currently set as "%1$s". If you need to make changes to this date, please <1>contact Valve here</1> with the reason for your new release date and what date you'd like it set as. You should be pretty certain that your new date is the date you will release.

Your base game and demo have different country restrictions. Wishlist emails will only be sent to customers that can access both. Base game: %1$s. Demo: %2$s.
App_Landing_DemoWishlist_Dialog_Desc: Send an email to wishlisters of your game, notifying them about the release of your demo?
App_Landing_DemoWishlist_Dialog_List: <1><2>Email can only be sent once for a demo release.</2> Even if you disable and re-enable your demo in the future, you can only send withlist notification emails once.</1><1><2>Steam will not email a player more than once within a two-week window.</2> If you release your full game within two weeks of sending this email, then Steam will not send release notification emails for your game itself to anyone emailed now. Plan accordingly.</1>

SteamLearn_DataSourceInspect_Error: Failed to fetch Data Source information
SteamLearn_Project_Empty: There are currently no created projects.
SteamLearn_Project_Snapshot_HMACKey: Copy Snapshot HMAC key to Clipboard
SteamLearn_Project_Create_Guidance: Enter a project name and optional description.  This will create a project that you can then further edit to add data sources and specify the model layout.
SteamLearn_Project_Create_BadName: Invalid Name -- possibly already used by another project.
SteamLearn_Project_Edit_Error: Error editing project -- please try again.
SteamLearn_Project_Discard_Warning: This will clear all unsaved changes. Are you sure?
SteamLearn_Project_Publish_Warning: This will create an established version of this project and create the tables necessary for snapshotting. Changing the data sources used will require re-publishing.
SteamLearn_Project_CopyPublished_Warning: This will copy all the settings of the selected published project over this unpublished project.  Are you sure?
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_SnapshotLocati: What kind of storage to use for snapshot data
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_SamplePercentD: The percentage of the snapshots that we will sample to train on. <1><2>Less than 100 will randomly exclude some samples</2><2>More than 100 will cause us to oversample (only useful if your sampling has randomness, for example when using something like a conditional extract)</2></1>
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_SnapshotTypeDe: How this project does snapshotting:<1><2>Manual - only snapshots on calls to SnapshotProject</2><2>Auto (Accounts) - Scheduled job that runs over all account ids, snapshotting at each</2><2>Auto (AppIDs) - Schedule job that runs over all AppIDs, snapshotting at each</2><2>Other Project - Uses another project's snaphsots</2></1>
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_SnapshotSchedu: How often and when the specified auto-snapshot should run.
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_SnapshotJobsDe: How many jobs to use when snapshotting -- using more increases load on the mllearn servers, but can complete the job more quickly (up to a point, where we start hitting sql contention)
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_HistogramDesc: There are times where you want to make sure that the number of training samples are similar for a particular data source element.  If that's the case, you can use a histogram filter, specifying a particular data source field a range, along with the number of buckets within that rate.  When sampling datasources for the training set, it will ensure that the same number of samples are taken from each bucket.  When choosing values, be aware that the sample count of all buckets is restricted by the smallest number of samples in any bucket, which can significantly reduce the size of your training set.
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_RangeDesc: Filter out snapshots that don't have the specified data element in the specified range
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_ExclusionFilte: Exclude samples by comparing their data files against comparison values. Exclusions are cumulative, so any of these filters being true will exclude the sample. Exclusion filters happen before inclusion filters, and any sample that has been excluded cannot be included.
SteamLearn_SnapshotFilter_InclusionFilte: Inclusion samples by comparing their data files against comparison values. Inclusions are cumulative, so any of these filters being true will include the sample, so long as it hasn't been excluded by the exclude filters.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_FetchWorkersDes: The number of workers that are used to fetch data. Wants to be set high enough such that it's fast but not overloading SQL, 64 workers is generally a good balance.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_SnapshotLocatio: Where to pull snapshots from during training fetch.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_FetchChunkSizeD: The number of rows in the numpy files that the fetch step creates. Larger files are more efficient to load and process, but can result in a less-well-distributed shuffle. Generally should be no larger than 1% of your total number of snapshots.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainBatchSizeD: The batch size to use when training the model. Larger batch sizes are more efficient to train, but may resolve less quickly. 2000 is a reasonable size for large projects.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainOptimizerD: Different optimizers have different characteristics and may be better or worse in different projects:<1><2>Adam - A high-quality modern optimizer that includes both momentum and smart learning rate annealing</2><2>AdaDelta - A more robust variant of Adagrad</2><2>AdaGrad - A broadly useful optmizer</2><2>SGD - A simple and classic optmizer, useful for shallow neworks</2></1>
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainLearningRa: The Learning Rate to use for the specified optimizer.  Setting to 0 will use the default.  Also can specify a number of warmup steps and the initial learning rate for warmup, along with the number of learning rate decay steps and the exponential decay rate.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainWeightDeca: The Weight Decay value to use for the specified optimizer.  Setting to 0 will use the default.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainClipNormDe: The Clip Norm value to use for the specified optimizer.  Setting to 0 will use the default.
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainClassWeigh: Sample label class weights and weight training to help with unbalanced datasets?
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainEpochCount: The maximum number of epochs to train your model. Small datasets tend to require more epochs (up to 100) but larger datasets often need fewer, sometimes just a few.
Maximum number of Epochs to train for
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_TrainLossImprov: The threshold at which we determine that an epoch's loss has not improved enough to be considered worthwhile.  Any epoch whose loss improves by less than this value is considered "not good enough".
SteamLearn_TrainSettings_ProfileDesc: You can specify certain batches in a given epoch to log profiling data, generally 10 or so batches is sufficient.  Setting to Epoch 0 disables profiling.
SteamLearn_DataSettings_SnapshotDuration: How many days to keep snapshots for. Snapshots older than this will be automatically deleted.  Projects that take a lot of snapshots can keep fewer days and still have enough data for training.  It's generally good to keep this under 30 days.
SteamLearn_DataSettings_FetchKeepCountDe: How many fetches of training samples to on the backend. Once a fetch has been cycled out, you won't be able to train from it anymore.
SteamLearn_DataSettings_CompressDesc: Should the snapshots be compressed when preprocessed for training? Enabling compression will make the fetch and train slightly slower, but might be useful if the preprocessing could cause large files (eg. large onehots)
SteamLearn_Config_DataSourcesDesc: The list of Data Sources that your project makes use of. Added data sources can further specify how each of their data elements are used by your model.
SteamLearn_Config_DataSources_None: No Data Sources current selected for this project.
SteamLearn_Config_DataSourcesDialog_Add: Select one or more Data Sources
SteamLearn_Config_DataSource_InputsDesc: How each element of each of the data sources is preprocessed and routed to a model input.
SteamLearn_Config_DataSource_Input_Prepr: The data values will be passed through to the inputs without being touched.
Compacts all values (must be integers) into a named table. This is useful for sparse or not-zero-based data. This table can be shared among multiple inputs.
Compacts a sequence of 1D data into a named table. This is useful when selecting from a limited number of sequences. This table can be shared among multiple inputs.
Auto-detects the full range of the data based on the incoming samples, and normalizes these values into the 0-1 range.
Normalizes all data within the specified min/max range into the 0-1 range, clamping any values outside the range.

Auto-generates a min/max range based on the mean value of the incoming samples and their standard deviation, and normalizes those values into the 0-1 range. Values outside of that standard deviation are clamped.
Normalizes all data within the specified min/max range into the 0-1 range, logarithmically (smaller values grow faster), clamping any values outside the range.
SteamLearn_Config_DataSource_Input_Explo: Show each individual element of this array, allowing you to specify different preprocessing and input routing to each
SteamLearn_Config_DataSource_Input_Colla:
Collapse the display to just show as an array, with no unique settings for any individual element.

Not allowed if any array elements have different settings
SteamLearn_DataSourceTypeMismatch: Mismatched key types on one or more data sources. Matching data from those data sources may not work during snapshotting and training.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Combine: Combines the data from multiple preprocessing nodes into one tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Shuffle: Shuffles all the elements of the input tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_SyncedShu: Shuffles all the elements of all the input tensors in the same way, preserving their relative positioning
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Onehot: Generates a onehot (or n-hot) based on the value(s) in the incoming tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Explode: Splits all the individual elements of an incoming tensor into their own one-element tensors
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Condition: Swaps the incoming tensors based on the side input -- when the side input is 1, the input and output tensors are swapped, when it's false they are the same
Extracts one element of the incoming tensors, outputting both extracted single element tensors and the incoming tensors minus the extracted values.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_KMeans: Takes n-dimensional tensors and generates KMeans clusters for them, or uses a named KMeans clustering to translate input values into a cluster index
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_TextVecto: Converts a text string into a numerical respresentation
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Normalize: Normalizes a vector so all its values sum to 1.0
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Reshape2D: Reshapes the tensor to be two-dimensional, with the specified dimension on axis 0.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_NamedInfe: Sets a marker within the model such that you can inference, with the connected node as output, using the specified name.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Concat: Concatenates into a single tensor. Input shapes must all be the same except for the concatenation axis.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Embedding: Builds an embedding from the values in the incoming tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_DenseStac: A series of densely-conneted neural network layers, with optional dropout between them
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Dropout: A dropout layer that removes some values of the input tensor during training
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_BatchNorm: A node that normalizes the incoming values to a mean of 0 and one stddev of -1 to 1.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Conv1D: Performs a 1D convolution on the data
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_MaxPoolin: Performs a 1D max-pooling operation on the data
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_GlobalMax: Performs a 1D global max-pooling operation on the data
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_GlobalAvg: Performs a 1D global average-pooling operation on the data
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Transform: A transformer node that mutates the input using attention heads
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_WeightedA: Averages along an axis with an optional list of weights per off-axis tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Dot: A node that computes the dot product between two inputs, with optional normalization.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Flatten: Flattens the incoming tensor to be 1D, usually for input into Dense nodes
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_SequenceS: Splits a 1D sequence into two sequences
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Extract: Extracts one element of the input values and either separates it from the other input values, it or generates negative (not-in-input-values) example
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_Train: Train nodes are responsible for taking the flow of the graph and training one or more model values against a corresponding number of supplied labels.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_TokenMask: Randomly extracts tokens from the list along with info about which tokens were masked
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_MaskedHea: Makes predictions about the masked tokens based on the input encoded tokens.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_TokenTran: Creates an embedding and applies a transformer to an input token list
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_ExternalE: Extracts the embedding values for the specified (non-transformed) key from another project
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_ExternalM: Creates an embedding and applies a transformer to an input token list
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Tooltip_RowExtrac: Extracts a single row out of the incoming tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_CommentDesc: An optional comment that describes what this node is for.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Input_InferenceIt: Add inference outputs to this input if we're iterating our inference
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Transformer_NumHe: The number of attention heads to use in the transformer
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Transformer_Feedf: Size of the internal feedforward layer
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Transformer_Dropo: Dropout Percent to apply after the attention and feedforward layers
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Transformer_Inter: The number of internal multi-head attention blocks after the positional encoding.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_WeightedAverage_A: Which axis of the incoming tensor to average over (and eliminate)
SteamLearn_Config_Node_WeightedAverage_U: Enable this to add another input which contains weights to apply to the off-axis elements
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Dot_NormalizeDesc: Whether to L2-normalize samples along the dot product axis before taking the dot product. If enabled, the output is equivalent to cosine similarity.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Delete_NodeDetail: Are you sure you want to delete this node? It will remove it from the graph and delete all its connections.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_CountDesc: The number of inputs and labels that this trainer will solve for. Must have at least 1, and at most 9.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_ActivationD: Which activation function you want for your output layer.

Useful when you have a value that you want to establish as true or false, and the result can be thought of as the probability of each. Softmax will ensure that a multi-value output will always sum to 1, so it's useful for distributional problems.
Will ensure that a multi-value output will always sum to 1, so it's useful for distributional problems.
Does no processing on the final output, good for regression problems where you're estimating a numerical value.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_OptimizerDe: Which optimizer you want to use for gradient descent.
A high-quality modern optimizer that includes both momentum and smart learning rate annealing.
A more robust variant of Adagrad.
A simple and classic optmizer, useful for shallow neworks.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_GPUDesc: Generation of GPU to use for training
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_LossDesc: What you want your trainer to solve for, by trying to minimize this loss value.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_LossDescSub: Good for models that want to predict a single True/False value. The label values will be either 0 or 1. The input value will range between 0 and 1, and can be thought of as the predicted probability of the result being true.
Good for models that have a number of potential results that you want to select from. The label values need to be a n-hot array.

Similar to Categorical Crossentropy, good for models that have a number of potential results that you want to select between. Supplies a single numerical value rather than a n-hot array, and is better for models with numerically large label spaces that only have a single value being solved for.
For regression problems where we're trying to estimate a numerical value.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_UsesWeightM: A tensor that matches your input data, that's used for masking which elements are considered when evaluating loss and accuracy.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_EpochCountD: The number of epochs to train for.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_CompactTabl: The compact name that the sparse value is referencing.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_NoImproveme: The loss threshold at which we'll prematurely stop training. Any epoch that doesn't lower loss by this value will stop training.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Train_BatchSizeDe: Size of the batches that the trainer will use. Smaller batches can make your train converge more quickly, but are less stable and take longer to train per epoch. Must be at least 100.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Concat_NumInputsD: The number of inputs to concatenate together. Lowering input counts can remove connections.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_KMeans_GenerateCl: Set to generate the clusters for the specified name. Exactly one KMeans node should be set to generate the clusters, all other nodes can just use those generated clusters,
SteamLearn_Config_Node_KMeans_NumCluster: The number of clusters to generate from the input data.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_KMeans_NameDesc: Name to uniquely refer to this KMeans cluster, for use in decoding output or querying cluster locations/radii.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Embedding_MaxValu: The maximum value that this embedding node will accept as an input. Can either be set to a specific numerical value, or a compact table name, in which case it will pull the maximum value from that table.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Embedding_WidthDe: The size of the embedding that each input element will correspond to.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_NameDesc: Optional name to extract the embedding weights to.  For use in similarity queries.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Embedding_OutputS: Embedding outputs are naturally multidimensional (embedding-width by number-of-input-values), but they are often flattened into a 1-height tensor, which you can opt for here.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Embedding_NameDes: Name to uniquely refer to this embedding, for sharing the same embedding across several nodes.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Dense_WidthDesc: The width of the interconnected layer.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Onehot_WidthDesc: How many values ('bits') this onehot should have, or a compact table name to use for sizing.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Onehot_MultiHotDe: Whether, when getting multiple input values, to set multiple values to 1, or output a two-dimensional list of onehots
SteamLearn_Config_Node_SequenceSplit_Hea: Chance that the split happens at the head of the sequence (returning the full sequence in the second output)
SteamLearn_Config_Node_SequenceSplit_Mid: Chance that the split happens in the middle of the elements of the sequence
SteamLearn_Config_Node_SequenceSplit_Tai: Chance that the split happens at the tail of the list (returning the full sequence in the first output)
SteamLearn_Config_Node_SequenceSplit_Seq: Name of the sequence table to split
SteamLearn_Config_Node_SequenceSplit_Com: Optional name of the compact table of the individual elements of the sequence
SteamLearn_Config_Node_SequenceSplit_Pad: If set will zero-pad both outputs to be the length of the original input sequence
SteamLearn_Config_Node_SequenceSplit_Ign: If set will only pay attention to non-zero values When splitting a sequence
SteamLearn_Config_Node_TextVectorization: The total maximum number of tokens it will track, throwing out tokens with lower frequency
How we normalize the incoming string data
Converts the text to lowercase and strips all punctuation
What the format of the output is
Outputs an integer for every token that is its index in the dictionary
Outputs an array the size of the dictionary, with 1s if the token appears in the text
Outputs an array the size of the dictionary, with each entry the number of times the token appears in the text
Outputs an array the size of the dictionary, with the TF-IDF weight for each token in the text
How to split/tokenize the input text
Does not split the input string at all
Splits at a byte level and then does pairwise merging for the most common combinations
Length of sequence in which to group the split tokens
Length of tokens that it will output when using Int output type
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Shuffle_ExcludeZe: There are times where you might have a list of values that is variable-length and zero-padded, and only want to shuffle the non-zero values. This setting lets you do that.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_NumInputs: The number of inputs to extract corresponding elements from. The first value is always the "primary" one when using things like AppID options.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_InputType: The data type of the main input value.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_ModeDesc: Whether you want to extract one of the input values, or generate a positive/negative example
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_Exclusion: Whether you want to exclude some values entirely
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_Selection: How values are selected for extraction (all among non-zero values)
Limit to AppIDs released in the most recent N months.
The name of a Steam Festival to scope AppIDs down to.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_BiasStart: Bias to multiply selection weight with at the start of the value list
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_BiasEndDe: Bias to multiply selection weight with at the end of the value list
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_BiasInput: Input to use (zero-indexed) to supply selection bias
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_BiasStren: Multiplier for strength of the input bias
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_PosSample: What percent of samples should be positive (the rest are negative)
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Extract_CompactTa: Compact Table used for AppIDs, and/or for finding negative samples (if using Positive/Negative mode). If excluding any elements, also specifies the Compact Table to generate with just the remaining values.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_ConditionalExtrac: The number of inputs to extract corresponding elements from. For AppID extraction, the first input needs to be the list of AppIDs
What items are eligible for selection for extraction
All items are elegible for weighted selection
How do we pick among eligible items
The number of months an AppID has to have been released within to be selected for extraction.
Bias towards newer AppIDs when extracting.
Which input's value to use for weighted item selection (0-based)
How strong the weight biasing is
The amount of lowered bias (0-1) at the extreme end of the downward bias (oldest app release).
The name of the compact table that contains the appid mapping
The name of the compact table is generated containing just the possible extracted appids
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Combine_NumInputs: The number of inputs to combine into a single tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_DenseStack_LayerW: The width of each interconnected layer.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_DenseStack_Dropou: The percentage of inputs that get randomly set to 0 while training. Dropout combats overfitting -- it is a good way to generalize a model so that it is useful on any data, not just the data on which it was trained.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_DenseStack_Activa: The function that is used when training individual neurons, each activation has training speed and loss-reduction tradeoffs.
Good general-purpose activation function, efficient and simple.
Slower than RELU, but can sometimes result in quicker learning.
Alternative to RELU, though can sometimes result in vanishing gradients.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_DenseStack_Regula: What regularization to apply to the kernel of the Dense layer(s), if any.
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Conv1D_FiltersDes: The number of filters to apply (the size of the output space)
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Conv1D_KernelSize: The size of the convolution window
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Conv1D_StridesDes: The number of elements that the convolution moves as it progresses across the input data
SteamLearn_Config_Node_Reshape2D_Dimensi: Axis 0 dimension of the resulting tensor
SteamLearn_Config_Node_MaxPooling1D_Stri: The number of elements that the pooling window moves as it progresses across the input data
SteamLearn_Config_Node_TokenMask_MaskPct: What percent of tokens should be masked out
SteamLearn_Config_Node_TokenMask_MaskCou: Maximum number of tokens masked out
SteamLearn_Config_Node_TokenMask_RandomP: Percentage of the time that a masked token is replaced with a random token rather than the <mask> token
SteamLearn_Config_Node_TokenMask_KeepPct: Percentage of the time that a masked token is retained rather than being replaced with the <mask> token
SteamLearn_Config_Node_TokenMask_Output_: Input tokens with some tokens masked out
SteamLearn_Config_Node_TokenTransformer_: Length of the incoming token sequence
Size of the embedding used to encode the tokens
The number of sequential transformer blocks to use
Number of attention heads in each of the transformer blocks
Chance to dropout in the dense transformer layer
Causal transformers enforce strict ordering of attention, non-causal allows for bidirectional attention
SteamLearn_Config_Node_ExternalModel_Num: Number of inputs on the external model
Number of outputs on the external model
SteamLearn_Config_Node_ExternalModel_Pro: The Project to pull the trained model from
SteamLearn_Config_Node_ExternalModel_Tra: The Train ID of the model to use
SteamLearn_Config_Node_ExternalModel_Nam: The Named Inference of the model subsection
SteamLearn_Config_Node_ExternalModel_Fre: Whether to freeze the external model's weights, or continue to train them in our model
SteamLearn_Config_Node_ExternalEmbedding: The Project to pull the embedding from
The Fetch ID of the model to use
The Train ID of the model to use
The name of the external embedding
The name of the compact table to use for transforming the supplied value
SteamLearn_Status_Fetch_Status_Unpublish: Unpublished versions cannot fetch snapshot data.
SteamLearn_Status_Fetch_Status_None: This published version has no fetches.
SteamLearn_Status_SaveOrDiscardFirst: Save or Discard changes to enable setting train live
SteamLearn_Status_InferenceActive: Train is Active (if just set, will be Live shortly)
SteamLearn_Status_Train_Status_None: This published version has no trains.
SteamLearn_ManualTrain_Loading: Loading existing Fetch and Train versions...
SteamLearn_ManualTrain_Desc: This allows you to manually start a new train of this project.
SteamLearn_ManualTrain_Unpublished: You cannot start a train of an unpublished version of a project.
SteamLearn_ManualTrain_NeedSave: You must save or discard changes before you can start a train.
SteamLearn_ScheduledTrain_Heading_Disc: You can set the project to automatically train on a schedule. When complete, so long as the new train passes the accuracy threshold versus the previous train, it will automatically be set live.
SteamLearn_InferenceTester_Keys: Comma-separated Keys (entering anything here will override any per-field data below)
SteamLearn_InferenceTester_NamedInferenc: If you want to inference a Named Inference, specify it here
SteamLearn_InferenceTester_AdditionalDat: Additional Data (comma-separated, must not be empty, for categorical models this is probably how many values to return)
SteamLearn_Status_Error: Failed to Load Data.  Steam may be temporarily down, please try again.
ControllerSupportModal_PgOne_Instruction: In order to best describe your game’s level of controller support to players, we have a quick wizard with a few short questions. Please complete this wizard with answers to the best of your knowledge so that Steam can connect players with games that work well with the devices they have.

Note that any VR devices, including input devices, that your game supports should be described in the system requirements. Controller support described here should refer to your desktop or Big Picture mode support.
ControllerSupportModal_PgOne_Question: What kind of devices can be used to comfortably play your game?
ControllerSupportModal_PgOne_GamepadPref: Mouse and keyboard, but gamepad is preferred
ControllerSupportModal_PgOne_GamepadRequ: Gamepad Required; No support for mouse and keyboard
ControllerSupportModal_PgTwo_FullControl: Yes, my game meets the criteria above for full support
ControllerSupportModal_PgTwo_PartialCont: No, my game doesn’t meet all of the above criteria
ControllerSupportModal_PgThree_None: No, my game doesn’t support any PlayStation Controllers
ControllerSupportModal_PgFour_SIAPI: Yes, my game has full Steam Input API integration
ControllerSupportModal_PgFour_NoSIAPI: No, my game doesn’t make use of Steam Input API
ControllerSupportModal_PgTwo_Instruction: If your game has full Xbox Controller support, it would be possible for a player to launch, configure, play, and exit your game without access to a keyboard. To truthfully indicate that your game has full Xbox Controller support, your game would need to be able to do the following:

A player must be able to do everything in the game with only a controller. This includes getting past any pre-game launchers, playing the game, interacting with menus, changing settings, and exiting the game.
When the controller is disconnected, the game must pause unless it's a multiplayer game.
Any prompts to enter text must open a virtual keyboard on screen.
If your game supports local multiplayer, that mode must work with multiple controllers.
ControllerSupportModal_PgTwo_Question: Does your game meet the above criteria for full Xbox Controller support?
ControllerSupportModal_PgThree_Instructi: If your game has support for one or more PlayStation Controller models listed below, it should generally be possible to use those devices to do everything in game that can be done with Xbox controllers. In addition, your game must do the following in order to be considered as supporting PlayStation controllers:
Display the correct glyphs (icons) on screen when prompting the user to press a specific button on the controller.
Play the game, interact with menus, change settings, exit.

<1>USB/Bluetooth Note:</1> For PlayStation controllers on PC, it can be quite common for USB connection to work well but not have the same level of support when connected via Bluetooth. Please confirm with your tech team that the game does in fact work with Bluetooth before selecting those below.
ControllerSupportModal_PgThree_Question: <1>Yes</1>, my game supports: (select all that apply)
ControllerSupportModal_PgFour_Instructio: If your game has fully integrated with the Steam Input API, then it would work completely with just about any of 200+ models of controller that a player connects, including future models. To truthfully say that your game has this support, it would need to do at least these things:
Display the right button glyphs in the game depending on the major controller models being used by the player.
Automatically pause if controller is disconnected.
The player must be able to remap the buttons on the controller they are using either through an in-game menu your team has built, or by using the Steam configurator.
If you have any doubts, please ask your tech team whether they are using the Steam Input API.
ControllerSupportModal_PgFour_Question: Does your game make full use of the Steam Input API as described above?
ControllerSupportModal_PgFive_Question: Based on what you’ve told us about your controller support, Steam will show the following breakdown for customers:
ControllerSupportModal_PgFive_QuestionNo: Based on what you’ve told us about your controller support, Steam will not show any gamepad devices as supported.

KeyWizard_Request_notes: Please use the box below to also tell us about your intended use of these keys so that we can help make sure you are requesting the right quantity for your needs.
Recap_Stats_NoAppsIncluded: You have no apps as part of this event
Recap_NextFest_Apps_ttip: Demos of yours that participated in the event.
Recap_NextFest_TotalPlayers_ttip: Number of unique players that played your demo during the event.
Recap_NextFest_TotalWishlist_ttip: Number of new wishlists your game received during the event.
Recap_NextFest_PlayerWishlist_ttip: Includes games that players both played and wishlisted during the event. This is inclusive; it's counted here in addition to being counted in Total Players and Total Wishlists.

Create_Home_None: There are zero creator homes setup for your app. Please review creator home documentation for <1>developer pages / publisher pages</1> or for <2>franchise pages</2> to set them up for your App
Create_Home_Desc: Select an associated creator home from which to display items on your store page. This section will appear below your game's description
Create_Home_SortBy_Desc: Select the order in which to show all other items not listed as 'featured' above.
Create_Home_SortBy_Release_ttip: Sort the newest releases first. Unreleased games will appear first, ordered by their stated release date.
Create_Home_SortBy_Tag_ttip: Order the games by the similarity of tags to this game.
Create_Home_None_Selected_ttip: Does not display a list of games from any of my creators
Create_Home_Select_App_Desc: You can optionally specify one or more of the included games to appear first in the list, ahead of the automatic sorting.
Create_Home_App_Featured_Desc: Show these items first. Drag-and-drop to re-order selected items.
Create_Home_No_Featured: There are no force featured apps.
Create_Home_Selected_None: No explicit selection. Store will default to first Frachise Creator Home linked to this Game (if any).
Create_Home_All_Creators_ttip: Include all games from all of the creator homes (developer/publisher/franchise) associated with this game. Manual featuring allows picking specific Creator home to highlight. Algorithmic featuring will prefer first matching Creator in Franchise, Developer and Publisher order for display.
DLC_Dependency_Desc: Does this DLC require another item of DLC to function? Select necessary items of DLC to display as required. The store will automatically display this dependency, along with an option to purchase all dependent items together.
DLC_Dependency_Require_ttip: Dependent DLC is required for the proper operation and experience when playing this DLC.
DLC_Dependency_Recommended_ttip: Dependent DLC is recommended to fully enjoy this DLC.
SeasonPass_Desc: Season passes are a purchasable item of DLC with a promise of future content to be delivered to those customers, either as separate DLC releases, or as additional content unlocked within the base game.
SeasonPass_Desc2: To make this commitment, developers must describe each of the major content delivery dates and contents to players by entering each date and content below.
SeasonPass_Desc3: Use the general 'About This DLC' section above to describe the season pass in general, while using the content delivery dates below to specific individual content releases.
SeasonPass_Desc_Releasing: When you are ready to tell players that you have released content in the season pass, use the 'Mark as Released' option below and follow the instructions. Please review <1>Season Pass Release Documentation</1> for details.
SeasonPass_ItemNew_desc: Content Release is a specific deliverable a customer would understand with a date of expected delivery.
SeasonPass_Create_desc: Please describe your season pass content release to players.
SeasonPass_Miletone_desc: Internal Description - Tell Valve what you intend to include in this milestone
SeasonPass_Delivery_ttip: This is the date you intend to release this content to players. This date is used to set reminders on your internal Steamworks dashboard. Please use your local timezone.
SeasonPass_Backfill_date_ttip: When did customer first get access to this content
SeasonPass_Backfill_check_ttip: This is content that has previously released. When checked will permit setting date in the past. When published this will not notify customers about its release. Cannot uncheck if date is in the past.
SeasonPass_Backfill_warning: Cannot unset previously released without moving release date to the future first.
SeasonPass_BackFill_invalid_date: Date must be in the past as this content should already be released.
SeasonPass_CustomerDisplay_ttip: You can choose to display a more vague date to players if you are uncertain about the exact release date of this content.
SeasonPass_CustomerSubtitle: What is this piece of content called?
SeasonPass_CustomerDescription_Subtitle: Please tell players here about the contents of this release. This can be as short or long as you wish. If you intend to release this content as DLC, the description here can be the same as on the DLC page.
SeasonPass_CustomerDescription_Images: Images are rendered at max of 584px wide
SeasonPass_CustomerComingSoonDLC: Optional: Pick a coming soon DLC
SeasonPass_CustomerComingSoonDLC_ttip: If selected, then the description and capsule from the Steam store visible coming soon DLC will appear in the above descriptions
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_desc: Is this content available to players?
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_desc_backfill: Content is marked as backfilled. Optionally provide how this content is already available to players?
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_radio_label_1: As an update to the game - New content is included in the base game or using a hidden DLC.
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_radio_label_1_tt: Make sure the release your updated build and post a Steam announcement with details about the content
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_radio_label_2: As an item of DLC - New content is represented by a new DLC store page
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_radio_label_2_tt: Make sure to release the DLC and add the DLC appID to the Season pass's package so players will automatically get the content
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_update: Select an update announcement that describes this release:
SeasonPass_UpdateLaunch_dlc: Select the DLC that contains this content
SeasonPass_ShipDLC_ttip: List of store visible DLC that is associated with the base game; that isn't the season pass and isn't already linked to another content release
SeasonPass_AddLaunchEvent_ttip: Pick a visible and existing event under the base game that describes the launch. It will be visible from the Season Pass DLC page
SeasonPass_NoDLC: No DLC Found - DLC needs to first be released in order to mark as complete here.
SeasonPass_PassDue: Release Date is past due for one or more content releases. Please release this content or update the expected date.
SeasonPass_NoLang_Fallback: No %1$s language title, will fallback to %2$s language title
SeaosnPass_OptionalEvents: Optional: Also include an event describing the DLC launch?
MeetSteam_Intro: Hi %1$s,%2$s Where would you like to meet us?
MeetSteam_Desc1: Listed below are events that members of the Steam Team are considering attending. If you are also considering attendance, or if you live nearby and would be available for meetups, please let us know in the form below. We will use this to better plan our travel and event schedules. If you register for an event that we plan on attending, we will prioritize those who are attending the event before sending our broader invites.
MeetSteam_You_Desc: Let us know who you are and how best to contact you:
MeetSteam_You_Update_ttip: This defaults to the email address on file with your partner account. You can update if you wish for event communication to go through a different address.
MeetSteam_Events_title: Let us know which game industry events you are considering attending in %1$s.
MeetSteam_Events_desc: Indicates events that Steam Team members are planning to attend. All others, we are still considering.
MeetSteam_attend_ttip: Check any item that you are planning on attending, even if not confirmed yet
MeetSteam_others: What other events are you planning on attending that we missed above?
MeetSteam_NeverMet: Have we met you before in person?
MeetSteam_NeverMetNo: No, I have never met a member of the Steam Team in person
MeetSteam_CapabableEnglish: Would you be comfortable attending a talk or event that is primarily, or entirely, in English?
MeetSteam_CapabableEnglish_Yes: Yes, I would be comfortable with English as the primary language
MeetSteam_CapabableEnglish_No: No, I would need translation assistance
MeetSteam_LanguagePref_ttip: This is to help us determine if interpreters would be needed when hosting such an event
MeetSteam_PostSurvey_Question: Do you have any feedback about any of the Steam sessions you attended at Valve's rented space in Convene? This is literally a one-question survey. We’re just looking to understand if something stood out in your mind about content, quality, timing, location, or subject matter of the sessions, good or bad.
TimelineMarkers_Editor_desc: Icons created here can be referenced from within your game to mark up specific moments on the game recording timeline. Steam also has a default set of icons that you can use. See documentation for details.
TimelineMarkers_Editor_createnew_desc: Create a new icon that you wish to use on your game recording timeline
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_Name_Disabled: Unique identifier on public icons cannot be edited
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_Name_ttip: Used by API calls (max %1$s characters). Must be lowercase alphanumeric. At least 3 characters long. Additionally supports '_' and '-'. No blank spaces permitted.
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_Name_error: Identifier contains unsupported characters. Must be lowercase alphanumeric. At least 3 characters long. Additionally supports '_' and '-'. No blank spaces permitted.
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_Name_error2: Identifier cannot start with reserved word 'steam_' used for official icons.
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_Create_Descriptio: For each icon, upload a .png or .svg and give it a unique identifier that will be used by API calls.
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_SVG_desc: SVG icons will be presented in a 36px by 36px viewbox. Please author assets accordingly. PNGs must be square assets between 24px to 256px wide/tall.
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_SVG_create_desc: SVG icons will be presented in a 36px by 36px viewbox. Please author assets accordingly. PNGs must be square assets between 24px to 256px wide/tall.
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_SVG_warning_dimen: This SVG has a viewbox or width/height of %1$s and may display incorrectly as a result.
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_Public: <1>Public</1> - will be visible publicly once you publish
TimelineMarkers_Dialog_Hidden: <1>Hidden</1> - visibility can be limited to specific build branches for testing
TimelineMarkers_Error_PNGDimensions: Error: PNG size must be square. Same image width and image height.
TimelineMarkers_Error_PNGSize: Error: PNG size must be at least %1$s px by %1$s px and must also be square.
TimelineMarkers_Publishing_desc: New or updated timeline markers need to be published with your other Steamworks settings.
TimelineMarkers_Public_desc1: These can be accessed from all branches, including your default branch via API calls.
TimelineMarkers_Public_desc2: As public icons, these may be referenced somewhere and cannot be deleted or renamed. You can update the image if needed.
TimelineMarkers_Public_none: Create new icons as ‘public’ if you wish to stage for public release
TimelineMarkers_Hidden_desc1: Use hidden icons to test before making visible. Use sets below to associate specific icons with specific build branches if you need to limit access
TimelineMarkers_Hidden_desc2: Use hidden icons to test before making visible.
TimelineMarkers_Hidden_section_info: These icons will not appear in any builds
TimelineMarkers_MoveAllHiddenToPublic: Move All hidden markers to public
TimelineMarkers_Hidden_download_ttip: Builds a single SVG file which Steam can use for rendering the icons.  This will build a file with all of the public icons and the icons in the hidden set.
TimelineMarkers_Hidden_none: Create new icons as ‘hidden’ if you wish to test before deploying publicly
TimelineMarkers_Hidden_new_asset_set_des: Branch sets help you manage testing of hidden icons by limiting access of icons to just builds on specific branches
TimelineMarkers_Hidden_branchsets_desc: Limit icons to be visible only on select build branches
TimelineMarker_Clone_desc: Choose a published marker from the list below to clone into branch set %1$s. Excludes markers already in the branch set.
AssetSet_Branch_Dialog_Desc: Optionally select one or more branches to associate these items with. Any player running the selected branches will be able to see the assets. If any non-password protected branch is selected, then we treat the icons as publicly visible.
AssetSet_Branch_Dialog_nochange: No changes were made to the branch list
AssetSet_Branch_Dialog_updated: Branch list changes were made. %1$s branch names were added. %2$s branch names were removed.
AssetSet_Dialog_MustHaveName: Must provide Name for Branch Set.
AssetSet_Publish_Dialog_desc: The following icons will be published:
TimelineMarkers_drag_target: Drag a hidden icon here to limit access to only selected branches
TimelineMarkers_drag_target_public: Drag an icon here to make publically visible to all customers
TimelineMarkers_drag_source: Drag these icons to a branch set below to control visibility by branch
TimelineMarkers_drag_source_public: Drag these icons to the box above to set visibility to public
PublishedMarkers_Desc: The above branch sets and public icons can provide specific timeline markers to the following branches.  If a branch set doesn't have any published icons then its branches wouldn't contribute:
PublishedMarkers_NonPublished_desc: These sets of branches do not have their own unique set published file. Customers on these branches fallback to using the default branch's timeline markers.
